newsitem.title: UK: LME copper holds on to bulk of gains by close.
newsitem.headline: LME copper holds on to bulk of gains by close.

text.p: Copper managed to hold on to most of its heady gains on Wednesday afternoon as fears of further tightness kept the market on the boil.
Three months copper finished the afternoon kerb at $2,340 per tonne, off its 8-1/2 month high of $2,360 touched in the morning but up a respectable $54 on the day.
"It's a crazy market. Everyone is a bit nervous," one floor trader said, adding that market tightness was showing wild variations among coming dates.

The immediate squeeze had evaporated, with cash for a day going into a 50-cent contango after steadily trading in the couple of weeks preceding the February date at backwardations of $23-25, the LME limit.
But tightness was developing in March and April, traders said. The March/April and April/May spreads flared to $40 and $43 backwardations respectively, up $6-$7 from Tuesday.
The premium of cash over three months metal firmed about $10 to $85/7. In addition, the option market saw a boost in activity from Wednesday's spike, traders said.

"Most of the market makers are definitely long for the second half, but there's speculative players who haven't got them and want them," an option trader said. Volatility had jumped a couple of points.
June $2,400 calls had traded at 21 percent volatility and June $2,450 calls at 21.5 percent this morning, with interest shown in March and April $2,350s and May $2,400s, he added.
Options traders also noted news that Asarco had bought calls at a strike price of 104 cents ($2,292 per tonne) to hedge 149.5 million lb of production as part of a synthetic put operation.
Whoever granted the calls would have had to cover their exposure when prices jumped above $2,300 unless they already had it in their books, dealers said.
But the second stage of the Asarco's move would be to sell forward the same amount of output above 104 cents, which could cap the market, they added.
Many of the other metals took a ride on copper's coat-tails.

Zinc notched up a fresh two-year high of $1,235, coming within a whisker of the January 1995 peak of $1,239. Another burst of fund buying could take it through there, but chartists noted the 14-day RSI was in overbought territory at 74.
The market ended the day $17 higher at $1,230.
Aluminium tried to cement its foothold back above $1,600, finishing at $1,604, up $20. The next major resistance area was seen at $1,620, traders and analysts said.
Nickel leapt $255 to end at $7,910, but the market looked vulnerable, a chartist said.

"In the face of severe resistance on the approach to $8,000, nickel has now completed a small top area and the risks are growing that there could be at least a secondary correction against the recent uptrend," said chartist David Charters of Investment Research of Cambridge.
The immediate target was $7,500, where the rising 30-day moving average came into play, with major support pegged at $7,300/$7,400.
Lead gained $13 to $670 and tin closed unchanged at $6,065.
Alloy finished $30 firmer at $1,530.
--Eric Onstad, London Newsroom +44 171 542 8065
